pageTitle: Focus on Geography Series, 2011 Census - Province of Quebec
title: Table 7 Quebec – Population by five-year age groups and sex, 2011 Census
TableContextTimeStampBeforeTable: {1500=In 2011, the enumerated population of Quebec was 7,903,001 which represents a change of 4.7% from 2006. This compares to the national average of 5.9%., 1063=In total, there were 3,395,343 private dwellings occupied by usual residents in Quebec in 2011. This represents an increase of 6.5% of the number of private dwellings occupied by usual residents from 2006. For Canada as a whole, the total number of private dwellings occupied by usual residents increased 7.1%., 271=Chart A description: Canada, provinces and territories - Population, percentage change between 2006 and 2011}
TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {82171=In Quebec, 51.9% of census families were married couples in 2011, while 31.5% were common-law-couples and 16.6% were lone-parent families., 81891=In 2011, the number of census families3 in Quebec was 2,203,625, which represents a change of 3.9% from 2006. This compares to a growth rate for Canada of 5.5% over the same period., 134271=In Quebec, the three most common mother tongues were Arabic (2.1%), Spanish (1.8%) and Italian (1.6%), in 2011. In comparison, the most common mother tongues at the national level were Panjabi (Punjabi) (1.4%), Chinese, n.o.s. (1.3%) and Spanish (1.3%)., 124243=In Quebec, 7.7% of the population reported English only as mother tongue, 78.1% reported French only, and 12.3% reported only a non-official language, in 2011. In comparison, the national percentages were 56.9% for English only, 21.3% for French only and 19.8% for non-official languages only., 151639=Statistics Canada. 2012. Focus on Geography Series, 2011 Census. Statistics Canada Catalogue no. 98-310-XWE2011004. Ottawa, Ontario. Analytical products, 2011 Census. Last updated October 24, 2012.  , 61707=In 2011, the percentage of the population aged 65 and over in Quebec was 15.9%, compared with a national percentage of 14.8%. The percentage of the working age population (15 to 64) was 68.2% and the percentage of children aged 0 to 14 was 15.9%. In comparison, the national percentages were 68.5% for the population aged 15 to 64 and 16.7% for the population aged 0 to 14., 12539=In 2011, 80.4% of the population of Quebec lived inside a census metropolitan area (CMA) or census agglomeration (CA). That represents 6,354,799 persons., 113082=The average household size in Quebec was 2.3 persons in 2011, compared to the Canadian average household size of 2.5 persons., 107074=There were 3,395,345 private households4 in Quebec in 2011, a change of 6.5% from 2006. Of these, 23.9% of households were comprised of couples with children aged 24 and under at home, a change of -0.9% compared with five years earlier., 99035=Among couples with children aged 24 and under at home in the province of Quebec, 83.9% were intact families, that is, in which all children were the biological or adopted children of both parents, while 16.1% were stepfamilies, in which at least one child was the biological or adopted child of only one married spouse or common-law partner. For Canada as a whole in 2011, 12.6% of couples with children aged 24 and under at home were stepfamilies., 124578=In 2011, 9.8% of the population spoke English only most often at home, 80.0% spoke only French, and 7.1% spoke only a non-official language. In comparison, the national percentages were 64.8% for English only, 20.6% for French only and 11.1% for only a non-official language.}

textAfterTable: Quebec – Median age2 of the population in the last 90 years The median age in Quebec was 41.9 years. In comparison, the median age of Canada was 40.6 years.
